reviews.review_msg:
I took this class in Fall 2024. I never write reviews but when now that its enrolling season I remebered this course.
Prof Collins Ifeonu is by far the best professor I have had at SFU. He is intelligent, caring, and kind. And truly the type of teachers we need.
He teaches well SA150 was the best class.

He is far from being a sociologist. As an academic, he certainly has the ability to talk and write at length, though much of it tends to be unfocused. While he may be a decent amateur lecturer, I feel sorry for the sociology community that he's considered part of it. He does not represent the field well.

Absolutely loved this prof. Smart, caring, funny, and generally made SA442 really engaging. Not an easy class, and the readings themselves tended to be a bit dry, but completely worth it. Teaches you how to really analyze readings well, and class discussions are really helpful. 100% would take this professor again.

The professor is kind but expects bachelor program students to perform at a masters level. The readings are long and hard to read but besides that him and the TA are extremely hard markers. The grading criteria is not clear and there is a lack of information given regarding assignments. Do not take this class as an elective it is a GPA dropper.

He definitely knows what he's talking about and is not just mindlessly lecturing. He's one of the smartest people I've learned from and is able to think abstractly about seemingly simple ideas/ problems. Really helps his students to see the underlying forces behind the issues in the world today.

Seriously take this prof for your own sanity and mental health. His class is like a breath of fresh air compared to some of the other classes in the faculty. He's a tough grader for sure but he tells you exactly what you need to do to be successful. He's also really approachable and because he's so smart he is able to explain things well.

He's one of those prof that's you just never forget! So engaging and so thoughtful and caring. He also designed the paper in a way that it was fun to write as we got to watch a really interesting documentary and write about that. Great class, smart prof, what more could you ask for?

He's a very good prof. I didn't do well in the class as it was a 8:30am lecture and I could not bother to wake up that early however when I did go to class it was so refreshing compared to the other profs I have had. He's such a passionate lecturer that it makes you want to just keep listening and hear more of what he has to say.

Not sure what the bad ratings are for.  He's very smart.Hard marker but you can get a good grade if you put in the work. His job is not to give easy work but rather push his students to be the best learners they can be which he does. If you didn't do well you likely didn't pay attention in class. He gives you all the tools to be successful in class

I would seriously go out of my way to take another class with this prof and that's pretty rare to say when looking at the profs at sfu. He's so funny and engaging it's literally impossible to be bored in his class as he's either making all the students laugh or lecturing with so much passion and motivation. You can tell he loves what he does!

Wow! I've never met a prof who genuinely cares so deeply for his students. He never disrespects any students is on a mission to learn as many students name as possible. Tests are easy and exactly from lecture material. Tutorial were designed in a way to be engaging, fun and informative. He's very smart and super respectable.

Great prof! Single handedly made me switch my major to sociology. He is able to captivate the whole class when he speaks and he made a 8:30am lecture so much more enjoyable. No need to buy the textbook as he goes over eveything you need to know in class. Also uses a ton of examples to explain the concepts. Recommend for sure!

He is a super smart guy which allows him to explain tough and abstract concepts with ease in a way students will understand. He doesn't try to trick students on exams and everything he says in lecture is all you need to know for the exams. One of the best profs at sfu so far! Super genuine and caring as well which is hard to find in profs nowadays!

Loved Sa 150 with him! He is such a great prof who genuinely cares about his students and wants to get to know everyone. His lectures are super engaging and everything he says in lecture is exactly what is on the test. Although he does assign readings it's not needed to get a good mark in the class. Definitely recommend!

i had no idea what he was saying majority of the time, i found lectures unengaging, requires textbook but i read a chapter and whatever i read was barely in his lecture. only one essay and  2 exams. To atleast get a 78 on the exam you need to know each topic he covers fully and understand what it can look like in different scenarios.
Prof was nice but exams were really long and graded unfairly. There was one paper worth 25% there was one TA which marked harder than the other. Tutorials were long and became boring.

SA 150: exams were really long and graded unfairly, they expected a crazy amount for the written portions while only having the marks be out 5. Tutorials were boring, super repetitive and long (2 hours), sometimes wouldn't even get a break. I would recommend taking this first year course with another prof. TA's marked hard.

(SA150) graded one 4 major things, 2 tests, a paper and tutorial. the tests were heavily based on the lectures and tutorials (which were worth 20%) didn't help as much. he posts his slides so i recommend writing down things he says that may be useful in exams. i found one TA a harder marker than the other, so beware. overall, not an easy class!

Prof-Collins course material is interesting, his lectures are great, and he wants his students to succeed. Grading is tough, but it is clear that he wants students to critically think. Take this course if you want to learn, and not if you're hoping for a GPA boost or a class to skip.

This prof is kind, but has unfair grading. If you don't like group projects or unfair and difficult grading systems. Don't take this course. If one of your group mates doesn't show up for your presentation, he'll fail the whole group. No exams, only writing. Lots and lots of writing.
